facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 39 of 1955 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 39 of 1955. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 28, 1954 of Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 69 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 28, 1954, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 69 of 1954 arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Patna High Court case arose from judgment dated November 23, 1953 of Sessions Judge, Patna in Criminal Appeal No. 288 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated November 23, 1953, of the Sessions Judge, Patna, in Criminal Appeal No. 288 of 1953 against the judgment and order dated August 27, 1953, of the Munsif Magistrate of Patna Sadar.

facts.text: Sessions Judge case against judgment dated August 27, 1953 of Munsif Magistrate of Patna Sadar.

anchor.surface_text: of the Sessions Judge, Patna, in Criminal Appeal No. 288 of 1953 against the judgment and order dated August 27, 1953, of the Munsif Magistrate of Patna Sadar. Murtaza Fazl Ali and R. C. Prasad, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 25, 1957 by IMAM J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. April 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.-The appellant was removed from his position as mutawalli of Gholam Yahia Waqf Estate on September 1, 1951,

facts.text: Appellant was removed from position as mutawalli of Gholam Yahia Waqf Estate on September 1, 1951 by Majlis constituted under Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was removed from his position as mutawalli of Gholam Yahia Waqf Estate on September 1, 1951, by an order passed by the Majlis constituted under the Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947 (Bihar Act 8 of 1948) hereinafter referred to as the Act . He appealed to the District Judge of Monghyr,

facts.text: Appellant appealed removal to District Judge of Monghyr, operation of removal order stayed pending appeal.

anchor.surface_text: He appealed to the District Judge of Monghyr, as he was entitled to do under the provisions of the Act, and the operation of the order of removal passed by the Majlis was stayed by the District Judge pending the hearing of his appeal. A complaint against him was filed in the Court of the Sadar Sub-Divisional Magistrate,

facts.text: Complaint filed on July 1, 1952 by Mohammad Sual, Nazir of Majlis, in Court of Sadar Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Patna.

anchor.surface_text: A complaint against him was filed in the Court of the Sadar Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Patna, on July 1, 1952, by Mahommad Sual, Nazir of the Majlis, on the order of its Sadar. It was alleged in the complaint that it was the duty of the appellant to prepare a budget of the waqf estate of which he was a mutawalli,

facts.text: Complaint alleged appellant's duty under s.58(1) of Act to prepare budget for year 1034 (1952-53) and send copy to Majlis before January 15, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged in the complaint that it was the duty of the appellant to prepare a budget of the waqf estate of which he was a mutawalli, under s. 58 (1) of the Act, for the year 1034 (1952-53) and to send a copy of it to the Majlis before January 15, 1952. The appellant had deliberately failed to comply with the aforesaid provisions and therefore had committed an offence punishable under s. 65 (1) of the Act.

facts.text: Office of Majlis where budget to be filed situated at Patna within local jurisdiction of the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The office of the Majlis where the budget had to be filed was situated at Patna within the local jurisdiction of the Magistrate in whose Court the complaint was filed. The appellant was subsequently tried at Patna by a Munsif Magistrate with First Class powers and convicted under s. 65 (1) of the Act and sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 100,

facts.text: Appellant tried at Patna by Munsif Magistrate with First Class powers, convicted under s.65(1), fined Rs.100, default 15 days simple imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was subsequently tried at Patna by a Munsif Magistrate with First Class powers and convicted under s. 65 (1) of the Act and sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 100, in default to undergo fifteen days simple imprisonment. He appealed to the Sessions Judge of Patna who dismissed his appeal.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Sessions Judge of Patna, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: He appealed to the Sessions Judge of Patna who dismissed his appeal. An application filed by the appellant in the Patna High Court in its criminal revisional jurisdiction was rejected.

facts.text: Appellant's application in Patna High Court criminal revision rejected.

anchor.surface_text: An application filed by the appellant in the Patna High Court in its criminal revisional jurisdiction was rejected. The appellant obtained special leave to appeal against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant obtained special leave to appeal against the order of the High Court. It has been found as a fact that the appellant failed to prepare a budget of the estimated income and expenditure of the waqf estate and to send a copy of it to the Majlis before January 15, 1952.

facts.text: Court found as fact that appellant failed to prepare budget and send copy to Majlis before January 15, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found as a fact that the appellant failed to prepare a budget of the estimated income and expenditure of the waqf estate and to send a copy of it to the Majlis before January 15, 1952. The only question for consideration is whether the appellants failure to comply with the provisions of s. 58 (1) of the Act makes him liable to be punished under s. 65 (1) .

facts.text: Sessions Judge placed onus on appellant under s.65(1) to prove submission of budget, but independently found prosecution proved failure.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the Sessions Judge erred in placing the onus on the appellant under s. 65 (1) to prove that he had submitted the copy of the budget within time. This objection, however, does not require a detailed consideration because the Sessions Judge clearly stated in his judgment that apart from the onus, he was satisfied that the prosecution had fully established on the evidence that the appellant had failed to send a copy of the budget as required by law.

facts.text: Sentence was for first offence.

anchor.surface_text: We need not, however, consider that matter in the present appeal as it was conceded on behalf of the appellant that the sentence of fine imposed upon him in the present case was for a first offence.

facts.text: Bihar Waqfs Act, 1947 (Bihar Act 8 of 1948) enacted for better administration of waqfs in Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was enacted for the purpose of providing for the better administration of waqfs in the State of Bihar as its preamble states.

facts.text: Majlis established under s.5 of Act for Sunni and Shia waqfs.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 provides for the establishment of two bodies corporate known as Majlis to discharge respectively the functions assigned to them by the Act with reference to Sunni waqfs and Shia waqfs.

facts.text: General superintendence of waqfs vested in Majlis under s.27.

anchor.surface_text: Section 27 provides that the general superintendence of all waqfs in the State shall be vested in the Majlis, which will do all things reasonable and necessary to ensure that waqfs are properly supervised and administered

facts.text: Mutawalli shall carry out directions of Majlis under s.56.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 56 it is specifically enjoined that every mutawalli shall carry out all directions which may from time to time be issued to him by the Majlis under any of the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Previous Mussalman Wakf Act 1923 (Central Act XLII of 1923) for better management of waqf property.

anchor.surface_text: Previous to the passing of the Act, the Mussalman Wakf Act (Central Act XLII of 1923) was enacted to make provisions for the better management of waqf property and for ensuring the keeping and publication of proper accounts in respect of such properties.

concepts.interpretation: Mutawalli must prepare budget before Jan 15 and send copy to Majlis; failure punishable; provision imposes reasonable restrictions on mutawalli's duties.

concepts.unlisted_description: Duty of mutawalli to prepare and submit annual budget to Majlis.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, it is necessary to set out the provisions of s. 58 of the Act which are as follows : 58 (1) The mutawalli of every waqf shall, before the fifteenth day of January in each year, prepare a budget of the estimated income and expenditure of such waqf for the next succeeding financial year and shall forthwith send a copy thereof to the Majlis. The Majlis may, within six weeks from the date on which it receives such copy, alter or modify the budget in such manner and to such extent as it thinks fit.

concepts.interpretation: Full text quoted; Majlis can alter budget subject to waqif wishes and Act; if mutawalli fails, Majlis prepares it.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n each year, prepare a budget of the estimated income and expenditure of such waqf for the next succeeding financial year and shall forthwith send a c

concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions for preparation, submission, modification of waqf budget.

concepts.interpretation: Punishes mutawalli for failure without reasonable cause (burden on him) to comply with s.58(1) etc., with fine; first offence up to Rs.200.

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for mutawalli's failure to comply with specified provisions including budget submission.

anchor.surface_text: Section 65 provides that a mutawalli may be punished if he fails to comply with certain matters mentioned therein including his failure to comply with sub-s. (1) of s. 58. Sub-section (1) of s. 65 reads as follows : 65 (1) If a mutawalli fails without reasonable cause, the burden of proving which shall be upon him, to comply with any order or direction made or issued under clauses (i), (o) or (q) of sub-section (2) of section 27 or under section 56, to comply with the provisions of sub-section (1) of section 57, sub-section (1) of section 58, section 59 or section 60, or to furnish any statement, annual account, estimate, explanation or other document or information relating to the waqf of which he is mutawalli, which he is required or called upon to furnish under any of the other provisions of this Act, he shall be punishable with fine which may extend, in the case of the first offence, to two hundred rupees and, in the case of second or any subsequent offence, to five hundred rupees.
Accordingly, the provisions of s. 58 offended Art. 19(1)(g) of the Constitution The Act was enacted for the purpose of providing for the better administration

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 provides for the furnishing of particulars relating to a waqf to the Court, that is to say, a District Judge or within the limits of ordinary original civil jurisdiction, to such Court subordinate to the High Court as the State Government may by notification in the Official Gazette designate.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 provides that within three months after the thirty-first day of March next following the date on which the statement referred to in s. 3 had been furnished, and thereafter within three months of the thirty-first day of March in every year, the mutawalli shall prepare and furnish to the Court a full and true statement of accounts

Section 10 provides for punishment for failure to comply with the provisions of s. 3 or s. 4 by a mutawalli, who becomes liable to be fined a sum which may extend to five hundred rupees, or, in the case of a second or subsequent offence which may extend to two thousand rupees.

issues.text: The only question for consideration is whether the appellants failure to comply with the provisions of s. 58(1) of the Act makes him liable to be punished under s. 65(1).

anchor.surface_text: The only question for consideration is whether the appellants failure to comply with the provisions of s. 58 1  of the Act makes him liable to be punished under s. 65 1 . At this stage, it is necessary to set out the provisions of a. 58 of the Act which are as follows 58  1  The mutawalli

issues.text: Whether s. 58 of the Act was an invalid provision because it gave unrestricted power to the Majlis to alter or modify the budget prepared by the mutawalli without a right of appeal against the action of the Majlis, imposed an unreasonable restriction on the mutawalli in carrying on his occupation and offended Art. 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by the learned Advocate for the appellant that s. 58 of the Act was an invalid provision because it gave unrestricted power to the Majlis to alter 1036 or modify the budget prepared by the mutawalli without a right of appeal against the action of the Majlis altering or modifying the budget. The provisions of s. 58 imposed an unreasonable restriction on the mutawalli in carrying on his occupation as such. Accordingly, the provisions of s. 58 offended Art. 19 1   g  of the Constitution The Act was enacted for the purpose of providing for the better administration

issues.text: Whether the Sessions Judge erred in placing the onus on the appellant under s. 65(1) to prove that he had submitted the copy of the budget within time.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the Sessions Judge erred in placing the onus on the appellant under s. 65 1  to prove that he had submitted the copy of the budget within time. 1039 This objection, however, does not require a detailed consideration because the Sessions Judge clearly stated in his judgment that apart from the onus, he was satisfied that the prosecution had fully established on the evidence that the appellant had failed to send a copy of the budget as required by law.

issues.text: Whether s. 65 provides for imprisonment in default of payment of fine, given the sentence of 15 days simple imprisonment in default.

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out that s. 65 does not provide for any imprisonment in default of payment of fine, but the appellant was sentenced to 15 days simple imprisonment in default of payment of fine. Section 33 of the Code of Criminal Procedure read with ss. 40 and 67 of the Indian Penal Code appears to us to be a clear answer to this contention.

issues.text: Whether sub-sections (2), (3) and (4) of s. 58 amount to unreasonable restrictions and are severable from sub-sections (1), (5) and (6).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, nothing contained in sub-ss.  2 ,  3  and  4  of s. 58 amount to unreasonable restrictions on the exercise of the duties of the mutawalli as a person administering a waqf. Even if it were to be assumed that the said provisions amounted to an unreasonable restriction, sub-ss.  2 ,  3  and  4  are clearly severable from sub-ss.  1 ,  5  and  6  of s. 58.

arguments.claim: Section 58 of the Bihar Waqfs Act is an invalid provision because it gives the Majlis unrestricted power to alter or modify the budget prepared by the mutawalli without a right of appeal against such action.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by the learned Advocate for the appellant that s. 58 of the Act was an invalid provision because it gave unrestricted power to the Majlis to alter 1036 or modify the budget prepared by the mutawalli without a right of appeal against the action of the Majlis altering or modifying the budget.

arguments.court_reasoning: Power of Majlis to alter or modify is inherent in supervision under s.27 and s.56, not unrestricted per s.58(6), budget indispensable per Shirur Mutt precedent, no need for appeal.

arguments.claim: Provisions of s.58 impose an unreasonable restriction on the mutawalli in carrying on his occupation as such and offend Art.19(1)(g) of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reasonable restrictions for better waqf administration; mutawalli subordinate to Majlis; similar to prior Mussalman Wakf Act and Shirur Mutt.

arguments.claim: Appellant's failure to comply with s.58(1) makes him liable to punishment under s.65(1).

anchor.surface_text: It has been found as a fact that the appellant failed to prepare a budget of the estimated income and expenditure of the waqf estate and to send a copy of it to the Majlis before January 15, 1952.

arguments.claim: Provisions of s.58(1) clearly require mutawalli to prepare and send budget copy before Jan 15, non-compliance punishable under s.65(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the provisions of s. 58 1  that before January 15, each year, the mutawalli of each waqf shall prepare a budget for the next succeeding financial year and shall forthwith send a copy thereof to the Majlis. Under s. 65  1 , if he fails to comply with the above, he is liable to be punished with fine.

arguments.claim: Sub-ss.(2),(3),(4) of s.58 do not amount to unreasonable restrictions; even if assumed so, severable from sub-ss.(1),(5),(6).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, numberhing companytained in sub-ss.  2 ,  3  and  4  of s. 58 amount to unreasonable restrictions on the exercise of the duties of the mutawalli as a person administering a waqf. Even if it were to be assumed that the said provisions amounted to an unreasonable restriction, sub-ss.  2 ,  3  and  4  are clearly severable from sub-ss.  1 ,  5  and  6  of s. 58.

arguments.claim: Provisions of s.58 are reasonable restrictions on mutawalli's duties; do not offend Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: we are of the opinion that the provisions of s. 58 of the Act are reasonable restrictions on the exercise of his duties as a mutawalli and it cannot be said that the provisions of s. 58 offend any of the provisions of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Majlis power to alter budget not unreasonable per Shirur Mutt precedent; budget indispensable; no need for appeal provision.

anchor.surface_text: As was said in the case of The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1  a budget is indispensable in all public institutions and that it is number per se  1  1954 S.C.R. 1005, 1037. 1038 unreasonable to provide for the budget of a religious institution being prepared under the supervision of the Commissioner or the Area Committee.

arguments.claim: Sentence under s.65 for second/subsequent offence up to Rs.500, but conceded as first offence.

anchor.surface_text: We need number, however, companysider that matter in the present appeal as it was companyceded on behalf of the appellant that the sentence of fine imposed upon him in the present case was for a first offence.

holdings.text: Appellant's failure to comply with s.58(1) makes him liable to punishment under s.65(1)

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the provisions of s. 58 1  that before January 15, each year, the mutawalli of each waqf shall prepare a budget for the next succeeding financial year and shall forthwith send a companyy thereof to the Majlis. Under s. 65  1 , if he fails to comply with the above, he is liable to be punished with fine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.58(1) requiring budget preparation and submission by Jan 15, with s.65(1) explicitly punishing non-compliance without reasonable cause, applied to accepted fact of appellant's failure.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.58 are reasonable restrictions on mutawalli's duties and do not offend Art.19(1)(g) or any provision of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: we are of the opinion that the provisions of s. 58 of the Act are reasonable restrictions on the exercise of his duties as a mutawalli and it cannot be said that the provisions of s. 58 offend any of the provisions of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mutawalli subordinate to Majlis under ss.27,56; Act for better waqf administration akin to prior Mussalman Wakf Act; supervision necessary as manager/custodian; analogous to Shirur Mutt on budget indispensability.

holdings.text: Nothing contained in sub-ss.(2),(3) and (4) of s.58 amounts to unreasonable restrictions on mutawalli's duties

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, nothing contained in sub-ss.  2 ,  3  and  4  of s. 58 amount to unreasonable restrictions on the exercise of the duties of the mutawalli as a person administering a waqf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power to alter/modify inherent in Majlis supervision under s.58(6) limits to waqif wishes and Act; not unrestricted; no need for appeal as per Shirur Mutt distinction.

holdings.text: Sub-ss.(2),(3),(4) of s.58 are severable from sub-ss.(1),(5),(6); failure under latter still punishable under s.65(1)

anchor.surface_text: Even if it were to be assumed that the said provisions amounted to an unreasonable restriction, sub-ss.  2 ,  3  and  4  are clearly severable from sub-ss.  1 ,  5  and  6  of s. 58. Even if sub-ss.  2 ,  3  and 4 were struck down, the mutawalli would still be under a legal obligation under sub-s.  1

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical assumption; severability doctrine applies as independent obligations; s.58(1) stands alone for punishment.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge's placement of onus under s.65(1) requires no consideration as prosecution independently proved failure

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the Sessions Judge erred in placing the onus on the appellant under s. 65 (1) to prove that he had submitted the copy of the budget within time. This objection, however, does not require a detailed consideration because the Sessions Judge clearly stated in his judgment that apart from the onus, he was satisfied that the prosecution had fully established on the evidence that the appellant had failed to send a copy of the budget as required by law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent factual satisfaction by lower court on prosecution evidence renders onus issue moot.

holdings.text: Imprisonment in default of fine under s.65(1) is authorized by s.33 CrPC read with IPC ss.40,67

anchor.surface_text: Section 33 of the Code of Criminal Procedure read with ss. 40 and 67 of the Indian Penal Code appears to us to be a clear answer to this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory authorization for default imprisonment even where offence punishable only by fine.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1  a budget is indispensable in all public institutions and that it is number per se  1  1954 S.C.R. 1005

precedents.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents.cited_proposition: a budget is indispensable in all public institutions and that it is not per se unreasonable to provide for the budget of a religious institution being prepared under the supervision of the Commissioner or the Area Committee

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the Sessions Judge erred in placing the onus on the appellant under s. 65 1  to prove that he had submitted the companyy of the budget within time. 1039 This objection, however, does number require a detailed companysideration because the Sessions Judge clearly stated in his judgment that apart from the onus, he was satisfied that the prosecution had fully established on the evidence that the appellant had failed to send a companyy of the budget as required by law. It was also pointed out that s. 65 does number provide for any imprisonment in default of payment of fine, but the appellant was sentenced to 15 days simple imprisonment in default of payment of fine. Section 33 of the Code of Criminal Procedure read with ss. 40 and 67 of the Indian Penal Code appears to us to be a clear answer to this companytention.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction and sentence under s.65(1) of Bihar Waqfs Act upheld; all contentions of appellant rejected including constitutional validity of s.58

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the provisions of s. 58 1  that before January 15, each year, the mutawalli of each waqf shall prepare a budget for the next succeeding financial year and shall forthwith send a companyy thereof to the Majlis. Under s. 65  1 , if he fails to comply with the above, he is liable to be punished with fine.

It was urged that the Sessions Judge erred in placing the onus on the appellant under s. 65 1  to prove that he had submitted the companyy of the budget within time. 1039 This objection, however, does number require a detailed companysideration because the Sessions Judge clearly stated in his judgment that apart from the onus, he was satisfied that the prosecution had fully established on the evidence that the appellant had failed to send a companyy of the budget as required by law. It was also pointed out that s. 65 does number provide for any imprisonment in default of payment of fine, but the appellant was sentenced to 15 days simple imprisonment in default of payment of fine. Section 33 of the Code of Criminal Procedure read with ss. 40 and 67 of the Indian Penal Code appears to us to be a clear answer to this companytention.
